BL, within image: Yaffa, ancient Joppa / april 26 1839 ;
circled 7 in BRC in graphite
markings: printed BC margin: London, Pubd by F.G. Moon. 20 Threadneedle Street. Augt 18th, 1843. / JAFFA, LOOKING SOUTH.
portfolio: The Holy Land, Syria, Idumea, Arabia, Egypt & Nubia. Volume 2, plate  61
text:
The ancient port city of Jaffa stands on a hill overlooking the Mediterranean Sea. In the Greek mythology, Jaffa is noted as the place where Andromeda was chained to a rock until Perseus rescued her. In the Hebrew Bible, Jonah attempts to flee God by sailing a boat from Jaffa. Over the past millennium, the city has been captured many times by forces with varying religious affiliations. In 1950, Jaffa was annexed into Tel Aviv.



In 1838, Scottish painter David Roberts toured the Near East, making him one of the first British artists to gain first-hand knowledge of the region. He went from Egypt to the Sinai and Petra, arriving in Jerusalem at Easter 1839. Remaining there for a few weeks, he then continued north toLebanon and departed from Beirut in May. From the outset of his journey, Roberts planned to publish a great set of Near-Eastern views, which eventually appeared as The Holy Land, Idumea, Arabia, Egypt and Nubia. He worked with lithographer Louis Haghe (1806-1885) to develop a six-volume magnum opus, containing 247 hand-colored lithographs based on his on-the-spot drawings. To fund the project, he exhibited his original drawings in London and used the exhibition catalogue as a prospectus to recruit subscribers. Four hundred signed up, and the series was published in parts from 1842 to 1849.This was one of the 19th century's most elaborate topographical publications illustrated with hand-colored lithographs. It was also one of the last, for photography soon became the preferred medium for views of far off lands. Nonetheless, Roberts's and Haghe's prints remained central to understanding of Egypt and the Holy Land in Victorian Britain.
title: Jaffa, Looking South
